comments:
Finance 220 focuses on international financial institutions and international banking activities. It examines how current and historical events are reshaping the industry and concentrates on the basic analytics of managing a bank's exposure to liquidity, credit, market, and country risk. In addition, it considers how to evaluate and compare the risk exposures and performance of individual banks. Throughout the semester, public policy issues such as international debt crises and regulation are discussed.

Students had mostly positive things to say about the course with one student even describing it as one of his or her “favorite Wharton classes so far.” Another student liked the “discussion format of the lectures” while another “enjoyed the way class was structured, with current events at the beginning and lecture for the rest of the period.” Students felt that the course was “interesting” and that “the material was relevant” and “related to real life problems.” They also commented that they “learned a lot."

Overall, students described Professor Herring as “an authority in the field” and a “very knowledgeable” and “extremely nice and helpful” professor. Students appreciated that Professor Herring “made every attempt to make himself available,” and a number discussed going to see him during office hours. 

The students made few comments about the difficulty of the course although one thought that “the last exam should have been more in-line with the contents of the slides.” Finance 220 can be taken for the Finance Concentration, and one student described it as “a must for anyone wanting to better understand what’s going on in the financial markets.” The prerequisites are Finance 100 and Finance 101.
